import React from 'react' import { Grid, Typography, Card, IconButton } from '@mui/material' import { useNavigate } from 'react-router-dom'; import ArrowBackIcon from '@mui/icons-material/ArrowBack' const classes = { container: { display: 'flex', flexDirection: 'column', justifyContent: 'center', alignItems: 'center', minWidth: '100vw', minHeight: '100vh', backgroundColor: '#3f3f3f' }, myCard: { maxWidth: '90vw', minHeight: '100vh', position: 'relative', flexDirection: 'column', justifyContent: 'center', alignItems: 'center', background: 'linear-gradient(to bottom, #F7F61B, #168820)', padding: 3, "@media (max-width: 600px)": { fontSize: '1.5rem', padding: 1 }, }, myQuestion: { minWidth: '30vw', minHeight: '100vh', display: 'flex', position: 'left', padding: 3, flexDirection: 'column', background: "radial-gradient(circle, rgba(255,255,255,1) 0%, rgba(66,181,129,1) 100%)" }, myTitle: { fontSize: '1.8rem', opacity: '0.8', fontFamily: 'Varela Round', color: 'black', marginLeft: 5, padding: 1, "@media (max-width: 600px)": { marginLeft: 0, textAlign: 'center', fontSize: '1.5rem', }, }, myLabels: { fontSize: '1.5rem', opacity: '0.8', marginLeft: 5, fontWeight: 'bold', fontFamily: 'Varela Round', color: 'black', padding: 1, "@media (max-width: 600px)": { marginLeft: 0, fontSize: '1.2rem', }, }, myTimeText: { fontSize: '1.2rem', fontFamily: 'Varela Round', color: 'black', "@media (max-width: 600px)": { fontSize: '1rem' }, }, myImg: { display: 'flex', padding: 10, "@media (max-width: 600px)": { padding: 2, }, }, myText: { fontSize: '1.2rem', paddingTop: 0, paddingLeft: 10, paddingBottom: 5, paddingRight: 10, fontFamily: 'Varela Round', color: 'black', "@media (max-width: 600px)": { marginLeft: 0, fontSize: '1rem', paddingTop: 0, paddingLeft: 2, paddingBottom: 0, paddingRight: 2, }, }, myIcon: { width: '5vw', minHeight: '5vh', } } export default function CIRCULATORY_SYSTEM() { const navigate = useNavigate(); const handleBack = () => { navigate('/main/explore/') }; return ( I. THE FROG’S CIRCULATORY SYSTEM 1. Blood Vascular System a.) Frog’s Heart  i. pericardium – an enclosing double layered sac.  ii. ventricle – conical, thick muscular-walled posterior portion.  iii. left and right atria thin-walled portions anterior to the ventricle; the division between the atria is not visible externally.  iv. conus arteriosus - thickened muscular tube at the right side of ventricle; extends obliquely and divides anteriorly into two trunks.  v. truncus arteriosus – two large trunks anterior to conus arteriosus.  vi. sinus venosus – triangular, thin-walled sac on dorsal side  vii. interatrial septum – partition separating the left and right atria.  viii. sino-atrial aperture – large opening in the right atrium through which blood enters the sinus venosus.  ix. sino-atrial valve – small flaps guarding the sino-atrial aperture which prevent backflow of blood.  x. atrio-ventricular aperture - large opening through which both atria empty into the ventricle.  xi. spiral valve – S-shaped longitudinal fold attached along dorsal wall of the conus arteriosus.  xii. opening of pulmonary vein – opening at left atrium b.) Veins (Venous System) Veins are generally vessels larger than the accompanying arteries. They are not elastic and are thin-walled by comparison. They carry blood from the capillaries back to heart under relatively low pressure. Uninjected veins are usually filled with coagulated blood and appear dark and flat. 1. Precaval vein or Anterior Vena Cava - Two; on renters each antero-lateral angle of sinus venosus; each is formed by union of 3 veins:  a.) External jugular vein - most anterior; formed by the union of:   i. lingual vein - near midline, from tongue and floor of mouth.   ii. mandibular vein – lateral, from lower jaw.  b.) Innominate vein - runs dorsally; formed by the union of:   i. internal jugular vein – from interior of skull.   ii. subscapular vein – from dorsal muscle of shoulder and arm.  c.) Subclavian vein - most posterior; formed by joining of:   i. brachial vein – from arm.   ii. musculo-cutaneous vein – from muscles and skin on dorsal and lateral parts of head and trunk (may not be visible in skinned specimen). 2. Postcaval vein or Posterior Vena Cava - Single, dorsal, from kidneys to above stomach and through liver; enters posterior end of sinus venosus; formed by the confluence of:  a.) Efferent renal veins - several; medial from each kidney. Postcaval also receives.  b.) Hepatic veins - two; short, from liver just behind sinus venosus. 3. Pulmonary Veins - One from each lung; both enter left atrium just anterior to sinus venosus. 4. Abdominal Vein - Single, inside the linea alba; joins portal vein into right lobe of liver; formed by the union of:  a.) Pelvic veins - two; at posterior end of coelom; each as branch from femoral vein. The abdominal vein also receives.  b.) Vesicular veins - two; from urinary bladder. 5. Hepatic Portal Vein - Single, veins from the digestive organs (stomach, intestines, and pancreas) and the spleen join to form the hepatic portal vein that parallels the bile duct and divides within the liver. Blood from the liver (including that from hepatic artery) leaves by the hepatic veins and join the postcaval vein. 6. Renal Portal System - A renal portal vein runs laterally along each kidney and gives off several afferent renal veins into that organ. Each renal portal vein (common iliac) is formed from:  a.) Femoral vein - from anterior side of thigh (called external iliac vein) from origin of pelvic vein to junction of femoral with sciatic vein.  b.) Sciatic vein - from posterior side of thigh.  c.) Dorso-lumbar veins - several; from abdominal wall; blood from a hind leg thus may return through either the abdominal vein or renal portal vein. 2. ARTERIES (ARTERIAL SYSTEM) Arteries are thick-walled and elastic tubes that carry blood under relatively high pressure from the heart to the capillaries and tissues of the body. Uninjected arteries feel like tiny rubber tubes when pinched between the thumb and forefinger and are usually empty in pre-served specimens. Each of the two long forks of the truncus arteriosus are divided into three major vessels or aortic arches: a.) Common Carotid Artery (anterior arch) divides into:  i. External carotid or lingual artery - to tongue and floor of mouth  ii. Internal carotid artery – dilated as carotid gland at its base; dorsal to posterior roof of mouth and gives off:
  • palatine artery – on roof of mouth cerebral artery – into cranium, to brain ophthalmic artery – to eye
3. SYSTEMIC OR AORTIC ARCH (MIDDLE ARCH) Passes dorsally beside esophagus and turns posteriorly to unite with its mate and form the dorsal aorta. Each systemic arch gives off: a.)Laryngeal artery - dorsal to larynx b.)Occipito-vertebral artery - short; dorsal; divides into:  i. occipital artery - anterior; to side of head and jaws  ii. vertebral artery - posterior; beside vertebral column  iii. esophageal artery - to esophagus c.)Subclavian or Brachial artery - to arm (occasionally as branch of occipitovertebral artery) d.) Dorsal aorta - the union of two systemic arches which in turn gives off:  i. coeliaco-mesenteric artery – one; which branches into: celiac artery – one; to the liver (hepatic artery and stomach) anterior mesenteric artery – one; to the intestine and spleen.  ii. urogenital arteries – four to six pairs; to the kidneys, gonads, and fat bodies.  iii. lumbar arteries – several; to dorsal body wall and nerve cord.  iv. posterior mesenteric artery – one; to rectum. e.)Common iliac arteries - Each in turn gives off:  i. epigastric artery – to ventral abdominal wall; a small branch (vesicular artery) to rectum and bladder.  ii. femoral or external iliac artery – small; to anterior part of thigh. The common iliac artery then continue as:  iii. sciatic artery or internal iliac artery – to dorsal part of thigh, and divided to supply the shank and foot. 4. CIRCUITS - In vertebrate animals other than fishes, the vascular system is generally divided into two separate circuits: a.) Pulmonary circuit - carrying blood from the heart to lungs and back to the heart. b.) Systemic circuit - carrying blood from the heart to the body tissues and back to the heart again. In frog the pulmonary circuit is more appropriately called pulmocutaneous circuit since skin circulation is also included in the pulmonary circuit. ) }
